unkerpaulie

Genesis 4: 3 In the course of time Cain brought to the LORD an offering of the fruit of the ground, 4 and Abel brought of the firstlings of his flock and of their fat portions. And the LORD had regard for Abel and his offering, 5 but for Cain and his offering he had no regard. So Cain was very angry, and his countenance fell. 6 The LORD said to Cain, "Why are you angry, and why has your countenance fallen? 7 If you do well, will you not be accepted? And if you do not do well, sin is couching at the door; its desire is for you, but you must master it." 
 
 2 very important points are shown here to help you answer that question. first of all, abels offerings were the "firstlings" of his flock, which meant the first-born, or the best of his shep. though it didnt say cain brought his remnants or his second best as offering, it shows that abel did. in verse 7, the real reason is revealed: "if you do well, will you not be accepted?" whatever "wrong diong" cain commited, (possibly unfaithfulness, or maybe listening to the serpent, cant do much more than speculate), both cain and God knew what wrong cain was doing. this is the reason why God rejected his sacrifice

billsco

What use would god have for the "fat portions of them"?
 Was this story invented by priests to urge a certain type of sacrifice?

 
 It is apparent the priests were partial to something quite similar to USDA Choice or Prime. A carrot wasn't as much to their liking and not nearly as satisfying. 
 
 When there was a sacrifice (or more accurately, an offering) the priests were the immediate recipients of the gift. Certainly an animal such as a cow wasn't charred beyond recognition on an altar; rather, it was slowly roasted to perfection--ala Arby's--and the donor was told that he received a brief reprieve from an angry god.
 
 A mere potato offering might excite the wrath more than the pity of the donee.
unkerpaulie

What then, is the point of the story? Why tell us that god was upset, if you don't tell us what it was that upset him?

 because there was more to the story than just what type of sacrifice was offered. cain had the knowledge of good and evil in him from birth, so he knew what wrongs God was referring to. cain was given a chance to come clean with the crimes he commited, both before the murder and after. the specific sin that caused his offering to be reject isnt as important as the fact that God gave cain a chance to reconcile but he didnt. rather than condemning cain immediately for whatever wrong-doing it was, God explained that the refusal was simply the consequence of his action. rather than deal with it and make things right, cain's rage is fueled to the point where he killed his brother. even then, God didnt unleash his wrath upon cain, but gave him another chance. cain remained in exile for what could well be a few hundred years until he found his wife (which would have been one of his sisters or nieces)
 
 the point of the story, i think, is that God will reward you for doing good, and even if you if you suffer the consequences of the acts you commit, God is still gracious enough to give you a second chance
 
 of course someone else may gather more from the story than that, but thats like a nutshell view from what i see
jyoshu

Why was Cain's sacrifice not acceptable to god? Why was Abel's acceptable?

 
 Do you want to know the deeper, more exact reason? I'll tell you.
 
 You have to go back to Adam and Eve's fall to understand it. When they fell by eating forbidden fruit, sin entered the picture--at least that's the theology behind the story. A blood sacrifice, pointing to atonement, became necessary in God's eyes. There is an understanding in Old Testament (and ancient thought, period) that says remission of sin and pleasing God or gods comes about by the shedding of blood. That is why many religions had a sacrificial system, not just Judaism. And if you still don't believe me, read Hebrews 9:22. 
 
 Ever notice before that when Adam and Eve made fig leaves for themselves that God didn't go for that, and instead gave them animal skins? It was because blood had to be shed over sin. He probably didn't just create the skins--he killed some animals to get them. It "covered" their shame, just like atonement covers sin. All of this is very deep and very representational--there are deeper meanings here than at face value. The clothing by blood-shed would only suffice for covering the shame of nakedness (realization of their sin).
 
 Cain had a sacrifice of crops; Abel had a sacrifice of the firstborn animal--a blood sacrifice, which was what God expected. That's why God didn't accept it. It's not directly stated in the text, but through the eyes of an ancient reader, who understood the way people viewed these things like sacrifice, the reason would have been clear.

 I assume that you refer here to the death of Jesus as a sacrificial atonement demanded by God. I think it's probably more realistic to say that Jesus died because both he and his followers overplayed their hand with regard to the Romans and that the Romans considered Jesus to be a potential threat to peace and stability in the region (temple disturbance on the eve of Passover, "King of the Jews", etc.). Jesus' followers were then left with the task of coming up with an explanation for his death by execution. Your view of God is nothing like the people who lived in ancient times where the most popular religions today originated.

 
 Please consider the following...
 
 "The reader must understand that the Torah contains a great variety of material: laws, narratives, history, folk tales, songs, proverbial sayings, poetry, and, in the early parts of Genesis, myths and legends."
 
 "Contemporary readers are often put off because they have been exposed to a method of biblical interpretation which understands the text in a literal way. Thus, if Genesis says that God created woman out of the rib of man, or tells of a serpent speaking, or of ancient man living several hundred years, the literalist interprets the story to mean precisely what the words convey. The contemporary reader familiar with the history and nature of the text will have to remember that a literal understanding of the Torah may lead to grave misconceptions."
 
 "This commentary proceeds from the assumption that the Torah is a book which had its origin in the hearts and minds of the Jewish people."
 
 "While God is not the author of the Torah in the fundamentalist sense, the Torah is a book about humanity's understanding of and experience with God. We believe that it is possible to say: The Torah is ancient Israel's distinctive record of its search for God. It attempts to record the meeting of the human and the Divine, the great moments of encounter."
 
 "God is not the author of the text, the people are; but God's voice may be heard through theirs if we listen with open minds." -- The Torah, A Modern Commentary, Union of American Hebrew Congregations Pub., New York
 
 Furthermore, as we can see from NT writings, more than a few followers of Jesus believed that certain diseases, including epilepsy, were the result of demonic possession. We're told that Jesus could cast out these demons and that he instructed his followers to do likewise. We're also told that Jesus' followers could drink poison without fear of harm. 
 
 Comments?

Pity those poor people in the Old Testament not pre-ordained for the priestcraft, the ones who mucked and scratched to feed their families. Yet as hard as times were then, the threat from a god who was always close to smoting them never abated. Tell a man just once that he wasn't completely depraved and it was likely the priests would lose control of him forever. It never dawned on the priestcraft to pity the wretched farmer and his family, and they continued to write stricter laws--disguised as imminent warnings from a god who had a thunderbolt wound up and ready to deliver--concerning the quality of the sacrifices. Nothing but the best, or else. 
 
 Deuteronomy 17:1 
 
 "Thou shalt not sacrifice unto the LORD thy God any bullock, or sheep, wherein is blemish, or any evilfavouredness: for that is an abomination unto the LORD thy God."
 
 The priests are claiming they know firsthand what is and isn't satisfactory to God. It closely matches their tastes and egos.

I think it's probably more realistic to say that Jesus died because both he and his followers overplayed their hand with regard to the Romans and that the Romans considered Jesus to be a potential threat to peace and stability in the region (temple disturbance on the eve of Passover, "King of the Jews", etc.). Jesus' followers were then left with the task of coming up with an explanation for his death by execution. They went even further than this and predicted his imminent second coming heralding the 'end times'.

John's first words to Jesus was "Behold the lamb of God that takes away the sins of the world." this one statement summed up Jesus' purpose entirely, long before any of his disciple even ever heard of him.

 Well, it sure wasn't Lucifer's favorite spot. He would have rather taken over God's house and run things from "on high". But, being the most beautiful of all the angels, he was given the Garden of God (Eden) as his dwelling place. It had all that the earth was capable of giving and then some - things we cannot fathom in terms of beauty. But, since his rebellion, God took that away from him and gave it to Adam and Eve. What better way to have it wrenched away from them than to get them to rebel against God - the same as he once did.
 
 So God is responsible for allowing him to remain in Eden

before Jesus even started recruiting disciples he talked about his death.

 
 And who might have recorded these statements, and why would they have bothered to do so? See, this is a problem. We really don't know what Jesus said as opposed to statements attributed to him by his later followers, many of whom never even met him. I would include within that number Paul and all four of the gospel authors. In all probability none of them ever knew Jesus personally. So, we are then left with the task of attempting to make a distinction between statements made by the historical Jesus vs. statements attributed to the later cultic Jesus.

 the source that gave you the idea that Jesus was set up by his disciples and was eliminated via the roman judgement, is the same source that gave me the idea that Jesus had spoken of his predestined death from day one. why are you now questioning the validity of the source? could it be just as likely that whoever recorded those statements also recorded the trial and execution? i am giving you an explanation according to the story, not a verification that the story itself is accurate
Orion

the source that gave you the idea that Jesus was set up by his disciples and was eliminated via the roman judgement, is the same source that gave me the idea that Jesus had spoken of his predestined death from day one. why are you now questioning the validity of the source?

 
 Because I don't consider this particular source (the NT) to be objective nor do I consider it to be a first-hand account written by eyewitnesses to the life and death of Jesus of Nazareth. The authors of the NT were apparently attempting to sell a story the events of which they did not witness. Moreover, the story seems to have evolved over time. For example, consider the question of when it was that Jesus became divine - you will get four different answers, one each from Paul, Mark, Matthew/Luke, and John. These guys were unable to agree on the specifics surrounding either Jesus' birth nor his resurrection. They could not agree as to when it was in the course of his ministry that Jesus created a disturbance in the Jerusalem temple. Paul seems to have known nothing of Jesus' miraculous birth, and if he did, he apparently didn't consider it to be worthy of mention. These guys couldn't even agree on Jesus' genealogy. Finally, many of the NT authors were convinced that Jesus' return and the end-times were imminent, that Jesus would come floating down from the sky, any day now, to gather up the faithful as well as to consign the 'goats' to the lake-o-fire. 
 
 That's not to say that I'd trash the NT, but it does suggest to me that one should approach a study of the NT with an understanding that it is neither realistic or consistent in many of its assertions, nor does it appear to be a divinely inspired work.

 Umm...I don't think so. Sorry. 
 
 
God is the referee, the score keeper. he is the one that determines whether your efforts have redeemed you or not

 
 All well and good. But the question remains (actually, two questions), 1) what efforts are required for one to obtain redemption?, and 2) is redemption even necessary? I'll defer the second question for another time, but I'd like to address the first, if only briefly. 
 
 Jewish theology suggests that one must atone for or redress one's transgressions (sins) whether they be against man or against God. If the transgression be against one's neighbour, one must seek to undo the offense, make retribution, and to ask for forgiveness. If the offense be against God, one is required to acknowledge the offense and to ask for forgiveness. There is no room here for a proxy.

These guys were unable to agree on the specifics surrounding either Jesus' birth nor his resurrection. Paul seems to have known nothing of Jesus' miraculous birth, and if he did, he apparently didn't consider it to be worthy of mention. These guys couldn't even agree on Jesus' genealogy. Finally, many of the NT authors were convinced that Jesus' return and the end-times were imminent, that Jesus would come floating down from the sky, any day now, to gather up the faithful as well as to consign the 'goats' to the lake-o-fire. 
 
 That's not to say that I'd trash the NT, but it does suggest to me that one should approach a study of the NT with an understanding that it is neither realistic or consistent in many of its assertions, nor does it appear to be a divinely inspired work.
